title: When will the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) next screen two million or more travelers in a single day?
preds: This one already happened, so no one should be guessing less than 100%. https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput
Changing from 98% chance to 100% since we did it yesterday.
+10 on yesterday's numbers, I'll go back down 5 or 10 if we don't hit it after this weekend.

This is going to remain a dance on the tightrope for a while. TSA tracked nearly 2,000,000 passengers a day without a holiday effect (06 June: 1,984,658; 10 June: 1,975,189), however, it hasn't surpassed the threshold yet.
It seems there will be a few more (maybe up to five) days before the 2mn mark finally falls at the 11th hour of June. This must come as a surprise to the agency itself, as the staffing and recruitment for the summer travel season don't appear to keep pace with the actual number of travellers and the TSA lured their office workers onto the grounds with a bonus in order to avoid long lines and excessive waiting.
https://us.cnn.com/travel/article/tsa-short-staffed-summer/index.html Actually, if the TSA fails to provide an accurate and timely service, this could deter travelers from future bookings, but it won't keep those from travelling who have already booked.
A surprise shot on goal came yesterday -- almost 99% of the way to 2 million on a Thursday.
we are nearly there and I believe travel is going to increase already in June
we nearly beat it on Memorial day, so we have two more holidays: independence day and labor day to get another 40 k travelers.

Updating forecast: TSA reported 1.985 million  travelers on June 6th, representing 74% of travelers on that date in 2019.  The percent of 2019 levels has been inching up from around 60% in early May, and hitting 75-76% around Memorial Day.  If the 74% levels hold, then there would be seven days in June with over 2 m traveler (first: June 12). I see no reason that the trends towards 2019 levels won't continue. Still, including some uncertainty given lack of "holiday" events until July 4th.

I may be over reacting, but with Memorial Day out the way and the travel back for those that took a weeks holiday, I am worrying there are no other obvious catalysts for a “blockbuster” day, until July, even with continued opening up.

Numbers on a Tuesday (6/7) were over 1.8M when a couple weeks ago we were down in the 1.5M or 1.6M. Updating to add 8% to likelihood that we reach this milestone in June even though a lot of people may be holding back for July 4.
Misunderstood the question - was thinking it was asking about 2022 - oops

The 2021 Holiday season will likely mark the true return of the travel industry as enough people will be vaccinated and the rest simply won't care. Unless a huge spike in covid cases or a new variant emerges around fall/winter, travel should rebound quite handedly.

Only a 0.8% increase needed over yesterday's numbers to hit 2 million. I would be shocked if that were the high-water mark. There are still 3 more weekends left this month, very solid shots on goal. At this point in June 2019 there were a few subsequent days that were higher than the equivalent to last Sunday. Every day in the US, another several hundred thousand people become fully vaccinated from COVID, adding more and more people who want to travel.
With spikes in other states and countries , and peoples fears of travel this seems a fair assessment.
1.8m yesterday, a Friday, but not a holiday weekend.  Could easily get there this month

Whatever happens this summer, it is clear that the numbers will be driven by higher than (before covid) normal domestic leisure travel.  To get back to the total pre-covid numbers it will probably require international and business travel to increase again.  Two million though seems doable with just leisure travelers.  It came very close on the Friday before Memorial Day.  Even without the holiday though numbers were climbing week over week and if that continues, 2 million should happen in June.   The only holdup wight be the lack of another major travel holiday in June.  I'm guessing that as kids get out out school though and families travel for the summer,  it will push the numbers over the top. Airlines say booking are strong so I have increased my probability in

So we have almost hit this twice - 1.8M and 1.9+M over the past two weekends. I know last weekend was Memorial Day so that was an excellent chance at this, but There's still a lot of data suggesting people and airlines are getting back into the regular swing of things. I'm betting that if we do not hit it on one of the Friday's in June then we will for sure see it on July 4th weekend.
Pretty much 8 shots on goal coming up in June (Fridays and Sundays).
Playing dangerously close to line at 1.95m just a few days ago. When return flights start factoring in, the 2m level will be easily hit.

Okay, I will eat a little crow for being so confident that TSA would hit 2 million this past weekend (but it was darn close, 1.96 million on Friday).  This might be stubborn of me, but I am sticking with my 100% prediction that it will happen this month as people bolt on vacation over the next couple of weeks.  Will reevaluate in about two weeks.

Got very close but missed it around memorial day. I had thought it would have broken 2 million that weekend, so I'm coming down 10 on prior to July. Will have to watch how the next week goes and drop further if it looks like it's not continuing to get close.

I originally thought Memorial Day would bring a surge of traffic that would bump it past 2 million but it only hit around 1.95 million. I think the next surge in traffic would be July 4th weekend coupled with more vaccinations and more openings

The US just had the Memorial day (31st of May) which is a public holiday. TSA recorded 1,959,593 people on the 28th of May and 1,900,170 for the 31st of May (likely people flying for the long weekend). The next big public holiday for the US is Independence day (July 5th). The biggest thing stopping people travelling in the US currently is the pandemic, as more people get vaccinated I would expect there would be an increase of travellers. I think there is a chance that towards the end of June the number of travellers will creep up towards the 2 million mark (summer time and less restrictions this year compared to last year). But I think it is more likely to happen in July when the next big holiday occurs.  I have kept a bit in the October bracket as there could be a uptick in covid outbreaks amongst unvaccinated or other currently unforeseen circumstances e.g there seems to be a lot of systems being hacked and held for ransom, interrupting national services. As there have been successful attacks on major infrastructure in the US (and elsewhere), I imagine the air transport industry could be a prime target.

I have been slow to update my forecast. Initially there was little certainty about the vaccines and their rollout, and I thought all that would play out slower than it has. Looking back, as an analogy, I probably relied too heavily in demand performance after September 11, where passenger numbers took almost three years to return to their previous level. [1] Now, passenger numbers were more than 1.9 million on 28 May 2021. People are constantly making risk/benefit calculations when it comes to travel. The vaccines have proven overwhelmingly safe, wide swaths of the population are vaccinated, and I think after more than a year of this pandemic, there is pent-up demand. I am revising my forecast to follow the crowd, with a 95% chance that by 30 June 2021 the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) will next screen two million or more travelers in a single day. [1] Airline Travel Since 9/11, Bureau of Transportation Statistics - Issue Briefs, December 2005, https://www.bts.gov/sites/bts.dot.gov/files/legacy/publications/special_reports_and_issue_briefs/issue_briefs/number_13/pdf/entire.pdf

All there needs to be is one day that is 2% higher than what we had last Friday. It's hard to believe that Friday was the high-water mark for the rest of the quarter. The crowd continues to be under-confident in my opinion. In 2019, plenty of days in June had more air traffic than the Friday before Memorial Day. Heck, the Tuesday after it had more traffic.
Yesterday was 1,959,593. Only a 2% rise is needed to get to 2 million. The crowd's 94% odds of that happening are still too low.

Given the recent throughput figures near 1.86 million, it seems overwhelmingly probable to break 2 million, perhaps this long weekend or when most schools are out for the summer, which will be before June 30. 6/11/2021 Update: TSA screens 2 million passengers on Friday, June 11.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/transportation/2021/06/12/tsa-screens-2-million-people-first-time-since-coronavirus-lockdowns-began/
Reports of Memorial day travel plans look positive
A few days ago (5/23/21) it came within 10% of the 2019 numbers.
pretty good chance of hitting the number this weekend.
Huge shot on goal this weekend. Let's goooo! https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/airline-news/2021/05/26/flights-summer-vacation-2021-covid-travel-restrictions-airlines/5034442001/

Updated my charts of TSA data here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/16EzHQrlHHYKuOEOYBdwndmV1xPx4SQJrnY-RdjwoIo4/edit#gid=0 Best I can tell the TSA forecast for 2.5m passengers is for the long weekend, not a single day. When I looked at Memorial Day 2019, there was no discernible surge of passengers on any single day of the holiday weekend. We are seeing a general trend upward and single days spikes above 1.85m. I am pulling my forecast forward, but not by much. I think the GJO consensus remains quite overly aggressive.
MEMORIAL DAY  WILL START IT OFF
The crowd's 91% is still too low
I think it will happen at the Holiday season

1. even flight schedules (supply) are only a fraction of pre pandemic levels
2. anecdotal: in our firm (finance industry), we were on flights at least 2-3 times a week. I don't see that coming back at all
3. uncertainty around new variants
4. many countries are not out of the covid woods yet, reducing their citizens' travel to the US

Crowd average continues to underestimate the true odds. Yesterday (Sunday) was 1.86 million. All that is needed is another 7.4% gain to exceed 2 million. How can that not happen in the next few weeks, barring some black swan?
High school and college students are out for the summer.  People are clamoring to get out of town.  Will have a 2 million passenger day by next Tuesday.
The crowd's 89% is not high enough

This article https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/aaa-memorial-day-travel-forecast-wellness/index.html Plus some rudimentary maths - c 3m last year Memorial Day peak versus maybe 2m previous weekends, so at 1.7m it is east to support that number. Plus another month of improving trends potentially. Going for 90 / 8 / 2

Update: I go full throttle to 100% certain because of @Vidur_Kapur's confidence as well as the realization that even if a national security threat or glitch happens, which are each very rare events, there is still the rest of June until the bin ends and the July bin begins.

Crowd seems to be correct... but way too underconfident, in my opinion... reasons unknown. I wouldn't factor in older months or a month by month basis because it lags too much compared to the recent rates. I leave a percent for an unprecedented lockdown due to a national security threat or a cyber glitch or hack that causes a disruption to the air travel.

Using the TSA numbers it looks like it could be soon assuming it keeps going like it is. Maybe memorial day weekend? TSA has estimated 2.5M over the weekend
https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/aaa-memorial-day-travel-forecast-wellness/index.html

Using the TSA numbers it looks like it could be soon assuming it keeps going like it is. Maybe memorial day weekend? TSA has estimated 2.5M over the weekend
https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/aaa-memorial-day-travel-forecast-wellness/index.html

Likely to occur soon. Quick look at the data indicates that Sundays seem to be weekly peaks, and last Sunday (16th May)  was 1.85 million. Wouldn't be surprised if it hits 2 million on the 23rd of May! Small weighting given to later periods to allow for covid resurgence, but I think this is unlikely happen soon enough to stop the target being reached in the April-June window.
More than 37 million Americans expected to travel over Memorial Day weekend. This is 86% of the 43 million who traveled in 2019. This 86% is plenty enough to get us to 2 million screened in a day.

https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput
1.8 million Monday 17th May (Monday seems to be the highest day of the week).  Numbers increasing by 50-60000 per week.  Suggests that projections to 2m will just push beyond the end of June
Trend continues improving. Memorial day and summer holidays are ahead of us and likely to further increase number of passengers before end of June.

One week jump in the maximum from 1.71M to 1.85M. Only has to increase like that once more, and Memorial day is still two weeks away, plus the whole month of June if it doesn't happen by Memorial day. Pretty easy guess that schools getting out for summer break will drive up demand, too.

Sticking with my 100% forecast.  It will happen in the next month.  Early June, with schools out and the pent up desire to go on vacation, the two million mark will be hit.  The crowd forecast is hedging too much and not looking at the data.
1.85 million yesterday (Sunday). Memorial Day weekend won't have a day that's only 8% higher than that? I find that hard to believe. The crowd average seems very much understated here.

Updating this given the TSA stats are looking higher than they have been.  Four days in May the number of passengers hit 1.7million (13 May saw a peak of 1,743,515 passengers - a number not seen since November 2020).  What's more, no US holiday explains this increase in movement... so perhaps this is the US gaining confidence and returning to the skies.

"Nearly 2.5 million Americans are expected to fly over the long weekend—six times more air passengers than Memorial Day 2020." SOURCE: https://www.cntraveler.com/story/37-million-americans-will-travel-over-memorial-day-2021-according-to-aaa That Sunday could hit 2 million I would think? May 31, 2020 had 352,947 passengers screened. Multiplying that by 6 gets us over 2 million.

"While air travel will still be lower than 2019, the 2.5 million expected fliers represent a 577% increase from last year. Recent TSA figures also point to a strong summer for air travel: On Sunday, the TSA screened 1.71 million people, a new pandemic-era air travel record."
https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/aaa-memorial-day-travel-forecast-wellness/index.html
https://newsroom.aaa.com/2021/05/memorial-day-holiday-travel-to-rebound-to-more-than-37-million/ ["AAA’s projections are based on economic forecasting and research by IHS Markit, a London-based business information provider. For the purposes of this forecast, the Memorial Day holiday travel period is defined as Thursday, May 27 through Monday, May 31. The five-day holiday period is consistent with previous Memorial Day holiday periods. This forecast was finalized during the week of April 12."]
Ok, we hit 1.7m yesterday.  Have to change to recognise we could get there before end June considering it’s 6 weeks away

As of 5/9/2021 the TSA has screened 1,707,805 passengers. There's been a consistent week over week increase in daily passengers screened going back a month (that I have seen). I think with more people getting second doses and with Europe opening up travel again, we'll see a large spike in travel, especially going into the summer.
Numbers above 1.7 million twice in last three days. Memorial day weekend is my target.

For anyone who wants to look, I took the TSA data and dumped it into a Google Spreadsheet, graphed it, and added a line of best fit for YTD 2021 and also calculated & charted the 7d rolling average: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/16EzHQrlHHYKuOEOYBdwndmV1xPx4SQJrnY-RdjwoIo4/edit?usp=sharing The trend line has actually been quite flat since late March, with a very recent but modest uptick after a lull. While I think there is a lot of pent-up demand for vacation travel, plus a lot of cash in people's pockets thanks to successive rounds of stimulus, business travel will not be returning to pre-COVID status quo for a long, long time.

Data show positive growth over recent weeks (as oof May 8) and before end of May we will have a public holiday that is likely going to lead to a spike. Anecdotal evidence suggests businesses are starting to return to in person meetings and even some conferences are back on with limited number of participants.
Increasing confidence in this bucket as TSA numbers rise. End of May still seems like the most likely time.

1.7 million yesterday (Friday). Today and tomorrow should be higher. Just need a single 17% more-busy day than yesterday to hit 2 million. How is that not highly likely? There's still most of May remaining and all of June, and more and more people are vaccinated and ready to travel. I'm not sure what the crowd knows that I don't, but this seems highly likely to hit by 30 June.
Now all airlines are booking 100% of the seats on plane and not blocking middle seat [1] [1] https://simpleflying.com/delta-load-factor-caps-lifted/
Yesterday (Thursday) had 1.64 million. Odds of hitting 2 million by the end of June have gone up.
Still expecting to cross the 2M mark on Memorial Day Weekend.
We are already at about 1.6M/day with a good chance that it goes over 2M when school gets out. Actually, I'm going to revise this upward.

New covid cases are in major decline, as more and more Americans are vaccinated: https://twitter.com/FaceTheNation/status/1388876193198448645
Memorial Day weekend will be a huge shot on goal.

Passenger numbers have increased rapidly for the US and now reach nearly 1.6m per day on some days.
We are half way through bin 3 now and with business travel not coming back and the impact of India and so on I think this delays everything I think reaching 2m is now wholly dependent on international travel picking up and the situation in India is going to impact that.
Highest volume so far this year was registered on April 2, 2021: 1,580,785

Look at TSA screening trends pre-pandemic versus post pandemic and comparing them with the rising vaccination rate, as well as the declining new COVID case rate, it would seem that we are close to crossing the 2 million in one day threshold.  Factoring in the predictable weekend surges of people traveling, which is averaging around 1.5 million on Fridays, it would seem likely that the combination of Memorial Day and school getting out for the year that late May would be a good estimate on when TSA hits 2 million in one day.  The first couple of weekends of May should be watched closely.  I am modifying my forecast to zero out "Not before 1 October 2021" and reallocating that 4% to "Between 1 April 2021 and 30 June 2021."
Memorial Day week could nail it.

It is very likely that once school is out, as the vaccination numbers increase, and the COVID cases decline more people will be traveling.  2 million a day is highly possible by June 30th, but the transition to the new normal of the post pandemic could possibly linger through the summer.  As a result it is possible that the 2 million a day mark may not be hit until late summer.  Additionally, need to account for possible unforeseen issues that may impact summer airline travel and postpone hitting the 2 million mark.

Passenger numbers have increased rapidly for the US and now reach nearly 1.6m per day on some days. There is likely to be pent up demand for domestic holidays / travel.  But there is still a good bit of international travel yet to come back.  Need to keep an eye on the numbers.

30% of the adult US population is now vaccinated in 3 months 75% will have been vaccinated.
Those vaccinated people are going to want to move.
Good article on the subject. Looks like Memorial day is a likely candidate. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/14/upshot/airfares-summer-travel.html?smid=tw-nytimes&smtyp=cur
"If you haven’t made plans for Memorial Day, it may be too late" https://thepointsguy.com/guide/summer-travel-surge/
There is lot of pent up demand for air travel. Memorial day weekend is my guess
Although pandemic numbers could take a downturn, the progress in vaccinations means that people are much more willing to take chances on things such as air travel.
If it doesn't happen by Memorial day weekend, I'll be shifting heavily to bucket 4

CDC director warning of "impending doom" puts a bit of a damper on going out and traveling: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/29/us/politics/biden-virus-vaccine.html Also, the week-by-week growth in throughput has continued to slow, although it should be noted that this past Sunday set a new post-pandemic record, at 1.57 million. There are still plenty of "shots on goal" especially in May and June, but the odds are lower than they were.  On the other hand, I remain far more optimistic than the crowd due to the experience of Israel, where substantially all of the 16+ population is now vaccinated: https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/israel/  It's always darkest before dawn.

Definitely won't be this month. The growth has slowed. Bookings continue rising, however, and at least one airline expects all its planes in the air by May: https://onemileatatime.com/american-airlines-ungrounding-planes/
Recent peak is about 1.5 million. May 21 2019 hit near 2.8 million. Increasing confidence on April to June as vaccinations continue to ramp up and more people appear to be flying.
The acceleration in airline travel is diminishing

Traffic has come roraring back and it is less dependent upon vaccines than I would have thought with rate of increase far faster than vaccination rate.  
•	12 days and counting of over a million screenings
•	2 million looks to be a bout 83% of what the average for the same period (Now-July 1 2019) was 2,424,036
Likelihood of making 2M before July 1 is going up – barring any setbacks with vaccinations or virus variants
I am increasing the likelihood of sooner rather than later and still almost certainly before Oct 1. Though I am adding a little there for the possibility of a major setback.

Acceleration has slowed a bit, so can safely move March down to 1%.  Delta investor update says that bookings >60 days out are down only 3% compared with 2019: https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/27904/000168316821000930/delta_ex9901.htm  Assuming I'm interpreting this correctly, it's going to be hard not to cross the 2 million threshold in May or June.
I feel like we're seeing a huge uptick in flying in the last week or two.
Up to 1.4m yesterday, can't see 2m being beyond October 1
Still a long way to go, but an upwards trend seems discernible from the data. Vaccine rollout going well and suggestion that everyone could be vaccinated by the end of May.

I'm seeing these numbers continue to accelerate, so this is one of the questions where I have to pinch myself, believe what I'm seeing with my own eyes, and ignore the crowd. 1)  Numbers posted this morning were up over 30% compared with a week ago.  2) One analyst sees leisure bookings (which are leading indicator) lagging 2019 by only 22.4%: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/americans-ready-travel-bofa-sees-202323833.html  3) With that being the case, it's far more likely to hit 2 million sometime in April, May or June than it appeared a few weeks ago. Furthermore, there's still a greater than zero chance of hitting 2 million in the last weekend of this month.
Shift due to vaccine optimism and an anticipated jump in travel numbers around Memorial Day, or July 4th, big enough to tick past 2M.

I believe the Likelihood of 2 Million Screenings by the end of June has  increased but still I think it is more likely to happen in July Traffic is definitely increasing
Vaccinations are also happening at an increasing rate https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/26/health/herd-immunity-united-states/index.html
Herd Immunity - Herd immunity estimated around June most optimistic and counting estimated but unreported cases
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Johns Hopkins University Coronavirus Resource Center, Gallup. 
Graphic: Priya Krishnakumar and Deidre McPhillips, CNN TSA Traffic numbers
•	3/12/21 1.357 Million Highest since March 2020
•	3/14/21 4 days in a row over 1.2M
•	2 Million would be 15-20% below normal – When will we get there - ????

Stimulus payments are hitting accounts, people are getting vaccinated, and there's lots of pent-up demand. This weekend's traffic was up 20% vs. last weekend. Bookings are surging. For example: https://www.wkyc.com/article/travel/covid-travel-deals-may-soon-be-gone/95-b3cadc6a-927f-4fbc-86e3-0e9fdf55c8d8   ("Interest in travel and flight bookings are going to surge in the next four weeks, six weeks," said Scott Keyes of Scott's Cheap Flights.) This month will be tough, but there will be plenty of opportunities to hit 2 million in Q2.

There are only 3 more weekends this month, but I disagree with the crowd that it's 0% for March.  Friday had almost 1.2 million, as people are going out for spring break and as more people are being vaccinated.  Anecdotally, there are reports of things picking up, including surges in bookings: https://www.startribune.com/msp-airport-expects-spring-break-travel-to-make-march-the-busiest-month-since-covid-outbreak/600028962/ If those bookings numbers are representative of elsewhere, if spring break travel this year exceeds 60% of pre-pandemic peaks, then that means there would be high probability of a day this month topping 1.6 million, though I agree that 2 million is a bit of a stretch.  There will be many more shots on goal throughout April, May and June. Dr. Scott Gottlieb on CNBC said he expects April to be a much improved month with respect to the pandemic compared with February. Additionally, Spirit Airlines is expecting to be back at pre-pandemic levels by this summer: https://www.flightglobal.com/strategy/spirit-chief-bets-on-a320neos-and-a321neos-for-capacity-growth/142724.article

Bringing my forecast slightly more in line with the crowd. I see this more as an economy question than a covid question. I do think that there are some business travelers that are never going to travel like they used to because of the new normal and I think there is some tourism that will never come back. More important than how our habits will change is the fact that many people simply won't have the money to travel. I ultimately think airlines will shut down many routes and airline fees will rise above what they were pre-covid. I'm just slightly afraid that one freak travel day will push this question over the top.

Eyeballing the figures looks like we are running about 40 to 50pc of previous years rates.
People are travelling more and I expect international travel to start picking up at some point, but 2m was not reached on every day before COVID.  So let’s assume the following: 2.2m per day is average per COVID, so to get back to this we need to get back to 90pc of pre COVID travel. Therefore both international and domestic travel have to recover to 90pc.  It’s highly unlikely that international travel is anywhere near 90pc of pre COVID and domestic is probably at the most near 90pc. Airlines are also only scheduling about 60pc capacity which is in line with the numbers of travellers being reported (40pc less scheduled flights at about 80pc capacity (very rough maths)
https://www.oag.com/coronavirus-airline-schedules-data Of course we only need one bumper travel day to fulfill this question, but with international travel going to take longer to get back to 90pc it would take a massive boost in domestic to tick over the threshold.  Let alone the fact that airlines actually have to schedule more flights. It will tick up over the summer, but everyone is being very cautious and I’m guess international travel will take longest to recover.  Looking at the OAG tracker, globally domestic seats look to be at about 80pc of pre COVID, but business is about 50pc.  Uptick forecasted for next 6 weeks, but if the US is following that thread international travel is a long way off getting to the 90pc needed for this question. Oh and one last thought, while airlines will be offering cheap tickets there are a lot of people out there who have no money due to COVID restrictions, so is there the same pool of customers as before.  Yes well off people have saved more and have pent up demand, but the borderline customers for whom a flight is a big investment are probably fewer, this will limit getting over the 90pc threshold both domestically and internationally. Moving forecast for not before Oct up a little.

The most recent average for a week slightly less than 1M/day. People are traveling more, even now.
Travel peeks around holidays, people will take any excuse for a holiday, e.g. Memorial Day.
Vaccinated people will start moving about more, probably around July.
Slight tweak to the numbers, because in looking at 2019, I realized June is a big opportunity to hit 2 million

1.2 million yesterday, on an ordinary Sunday (February 28th).  A week ago when I put 1 Jan. 2021 - 31 Mar. 2021 at 0%, I didn't anticipate that. March is spring break month and there are more people getting vaccinated, and lots of pent-up demand to travel
Just hit 1.1 million yesterday. 31 March 2021 is now slightly above 0.

I look at the TSA numbers each day, and they are stubbornly low. Yesterday (2/23/21) was only 714k vs. 1.91M on 2/23/20. Charlie Munger in his talk today said he expects business to be done with a lot more Zoom and a lot less travel, so it's very possible that the 12% of travelers who are business traveler may *never* fully come back to pre-pandemic levels. So tourists will have to do a lot of heavy lifting. As such, it looks more like the 3rd quarter to me.
+8% to April-June, +7% to July-september, -15% to "not before".

Vaccination is progressing at ~ 0.5% of the population per day. New cases are dropping at ~25% per week.  By Memorial day weekend, ~60-70% population should be vaccinated. Weekly cases could be down to less than 100k. I am betting that Memorial day weekend will see record air travel.

TSA is DOT. They also screen highways and may augment border control. COVID will drive this one. Check point Charlie between states man in high castle is worse case scenario. California may expand agricultural to COVID and others. “Let me see your papers”. Hence Governor Newsome will be removed from office. Where does he get these ideas from?

Hit 1m travellers in the past week or so.  Been averaging about 900k over last few days.
Travel is creeping back up despite lockdowns.
But again, need international travel to boost back to 2019 levels and can’t see that coming quickly.  Maintaining forwcast
Memorial day weekend is the date I am feeling good about. The covid cases will be down a trickle by then.
My best guess is Memorial Day weekend or July 4th as the point where the number passes 2 million. Thinking being the holiday weekends/combined with increase in vaccinations.

TSA latest numbers: only 537,000 people yesterday compared with 1,777,000 a year ago. Business travel has very much collapsed and won't be back for awhile. Even if Spring Break in March is better than anticipated, 2 million will be a tough number to hit. Spring Break 2019 averaged 2.4 million a day: https://www.tsa.gov/news/press/releases/2019/04/30/tsa-hits-record-setting-numbers-more-108m-travelers-screened-during
-25% to April-June, +10% to July-September, +15% to 'Not before'.

To step completely away from the polynomial modeling I was trying on this question..... under a Biden Presidency I think we'll continue to see travel restrictions that will dampen travel by air [1] [1] https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/24/politics/biden-coronavirus-travel-trump/index.html
Vaccine rollout has slower than I anticipated. January 4th was the last time a million was exceeded
Roll out does not seem to be going great, so shifted 10% from April/June to later.

The vaccine rollout is slow. Update: The busiest days in TSA history are around 2.7-2.8M, which were roughly 500k (~20%) above the average at that time. Those peaks were around holidays (Memorial Day, Thanksgiving, Christmas), with Memorial day being the current record holder. If we see 7-day average numbers of ~1.6M going into a holiday weekend then we would be likely to hit this limit if we assume a 20% bump for the holiday. Bucket 1: no chance
Bucket 2: no chance
Bucket 3: If 5% / month trend continues, it's entirely conceivable we could be at 1.6M by around the end of May. That's the first realistic chance to hit 2M: Memorial Day, May 31 2021 in my mind. It's possible that we could miss Memorial day but still get over 2M in late June.
Bucket 4: If we miss in May, Labor Day weekend is our next most likely.

Update:  1) The busiest days in TSA history are around 2.7-2.8M, which were roughly 500k (~20%) above the average at that time. Those peaks were around holidays (Memorial Day, Thanksgiving, Christmas), with Memorial day being the current record holder. Generally speaking June - August are busiest months running 10-15% above the fall/winter period. 
2) If we saw average numbers of ~1.6M going into a holiday weekend then we would be likely to hit this limit if we assume a 20% bump for the holiday.
3) We are currently running about 57% of that 1.6M rate and trending up at 5% / month. Assuming we get a 15% bump in the summer, that will be 67%. I also assume an increase in the April - August period from a vaccine starting to increase confidence.
4) If 5% / month trend continues, it's entirely conceivable we could be at 1.6M by around the end of May. That's the first realistic chance to hit 2M: Memorial Day, May 31 2021 in my mind. 
5) The other buckets seem to be in play and it's a question in my mind of whether it's Memorial day (May 31, 2021) weekend or not.
6) the 4th bucket doesn't include any big travel holidays, even though it is the busy season. if we are back to BAU by then, going over 2M is possible.

"The busiest air travel day of the coronavirus pandemic came on Wednesday, the day before Thanksgiving, with 1,070,967 passengers clearing airport security ... It was the third time in one week that the Transportation Security Administration reported screening more than 1 million daily passengers — a milestone that airports have rarely seen since the pandemic slashed air travel in March ... The number of travelers flying Wednesday was half of what it was on the day before Thanksgiving in 2019, before the coronavirus was a threat in the United States. Last year, 2,602,631 people were screened on Thanksgiving eve ... Thanksgiving eve crowds surpassed Sunday’s busy passenger levels by 23,000. The Wednesday before Thanksgiving is typically the busiest travel day of the year, closely followed by the Sunday after the holiday." https://www.washingtonpost.com/travel/2020/11/27/flights-tsa-highest-thanksgiving-covid/

I think people who have not been able to travel internationally/domestically over the last 8 months will feel compelled to have a vacation as soon as they are able, meaning the number of travelers will exceed the same day number from 2019.  Therefore I'm shifting my forecast from a left skewed distribution to a gaussian distribution centered at the interval of 'Between 1 April 2021 and 30 June 2021'.

The current rate is at about 800,000/day. That number is keeping pretty steady, and only very slowly growing.
"Normal" rates, if we look at 2019 is about 2.5M/day. Getting to 2M/day would require a 150% increase in air travel, and would require us to get back to 80% of normal travel. It is very likely that the country will not open up and allow for much higher travel numbers (especially to get to 80%), until a vaccine is administered widely. Current vaccines are in 2nd and 3rd phases of testing, and will likely not be ready until at least halfway through 2021 (optimistically). Manufacturing the vaccines, and then distributing them will take an even longer period of time, say 3-12 months. The contrarian opinion would be that testing is getting better, people are getting restless and wanting to travel more, Christmas season will likely see a spike in travel, more people are more comfortable wearing masks, etc. All of that will help bump up numbers, but will very likely not contribute to a big enough jump in time On top of that, consumer demand has been lowered as incomes have fallen, and more people have adapted to a work-from-home remote lifestyle. Conferences will be hesitant to start up again to previous levels, and therefore it will take more time for business travel to resume. I would guess that the first significant surge that might get us to over 2M/day would be the Christmas holiday season in December 2021.

We can crudely group the population into thirds... A third fears for their life when a person sneezes across the street, a third has zero fear of Covid, and the other third is rational.  Demographically, the third that has zero fear of Covid is on the lower end of travel frequency.  The middle third will slowly travel more and more. 
And the third that is terrified of the virus will be hesitant to travel right away even after a vaccine is developed.  So while rationally, you would think air travel would spike after a vaccine is developed. There will be too many people with psychological reservations to get on a big enclosed tube of metal for hours.  There’s a chance we could hit the threshold on Labor Day. But more than likely we are looking at a T-Day or X-mas date of this coming to fruition

Ok, this time I'll actually look at the data. Clearly summer is peak travel time with the Memorial, 4 July, and Labor Days the penultimate times. Business travel may be premanently reduced going forward which will kill profitability for airlines and raise prices for everyone, thus reducing overall air travel going forward. Almost a million brave souls took to the skies this Labor Day, relieving pent up demand. When will this double? If a vaccine is effective and available to many by end Q1, there is a chance summer holidays by air will recover. So this question is about when will an effective vaccine be available to the masses. The fourth bucket has the highest chance of hitting 2M as it has both July 4 and Labor Day and the most time to get vaccines in people.

But airlines are signaling they believe this won't be repeated any time soon, as summer leisure travel comes to an end while business travel is expected to remain slow to return ... The airlines have made clear they're not expecting strong demand through the end of the year." https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/08/business/labor-day-air-travel/index.html

So far the 2020 peak post-coronavirus has been less than 50% of 2019 and less than a million. But the passengers have been steadily climbing since the virus first hit. There's a small chance holiday travel pushes it over 2 million this year, but I think that's unlikely, and increases in screenings have grown more slowly recently. Next year prior to March it could exceed, but those don't make the list of busiest travel days and if a vaccine is available by year end it might not be widely available enough by March to ease concerns. Because the peak is in summer I think that's when we'll likely exceed 2 million, with a low chance that it isn't exceeded by October of next year. April to June seems likeliest to me based on vaccine probability and those months being the start of peak travel. As long as Covid19 is SOMEWHERE it can be EVERYWHERE.  Each country's own response is only as strong as the worst performing country elsewhere.  NZ was doing very well reaching 102 days Covid19-free, but their recent outbreak came in via the border despite so many safeguards. Even if a vaccination is successfully developed against all strains of Covid19 within the next 6 months, it will take time (maybe over a year) before 70% of the world's population can be immunized (assuming that herd immunity is possible).

This is after the time I anticipate a vaccine will become widely available.  People will not start travelling again until a vaccine is established, and it is unlikely to occur before then.  Besides that, people like travelling in the summer, pushing numbers higher.  More people will also be screened on return trips once there are more return trips planned, which will lag behind vaccines becoming widespread.  People travel when they feel safe, and that won't happen while COVID is a consideration.  Travel bans can be lifted only once a vaccine is available, and most non business travel lags behind a vaccine.   It's all in the vaccine.

I think there is virtually 0% chance of this happening before the new year.  Cases rising steadily and only expected to continue with cooler weather, more time indoors, in-person schools, and 1000+ person maskless political campaigns underway for the next several weeks. Even if people are ready to travel, many of their employers aren’t convinced it is worth the risk unless the travel is essential for job functioning. Adjusting to reflect the well-thought-out reasoning of @Dillyweed

In a press release from 1 Sept 2020 when discussing the 80-20 use-it-or-lose-it slot rule for the winter 2020 season, Alexandre de Juniac, International Air Transport Association CEO, said “… Europe is underestimating the challenge and dragging its feet. Somehow, they believe that demand could rebound to 75% or even 85% of last years [SIC] levels by early 2021. That is much more optimistic than any industry forecast, or the evolution of traffic seen over the peak summer season.” https://www.iata.org/en/pressroom/pr/2020-09-01-02/ In late July 2020, OAG was reporting that the four major US airlines are planning on operating about half their capacity for the Winter 2020 schedule. https://www.oag.com/blog/oag-coronavirus-update-week-twentyseven This leads to my forecast of only a 15% chance of passenger traffic coming back March 2020 levels before 1 October 2021.

Here's how I'm thinking abou this: 1) The busiest days in TSA history are around 2.7-2.8M, which were roughly 500k (~20%) above the average at that time. Those peaks were around holidays (Memorial Day, Thanksgiving, Christmas), with Memorial day being the current record holder. Generally speaking June - August are busiest months running 10-15% above the fall/winter period.
2) assuming peak travel around holidays remains the norm (and I have no reason to believe that's not the case), then if we saw average numbers of ~1.6M going into Thanksgiving, Xmas or Memorial day then we would be likely to hit this limit if we assume a 20% bump for the holiday.
3) 1.6M per day is almost 3x our current level and it is currently trending flat to down. Plus I would expect seasonal factors to be a headwind. To be clear: I do expect it to go up, but just not by 3x before December 31. 
4) The next bucket is before the peak season and doesn't include any major travel holidays. If we don't get there by Dec 31st, then we're not getting there by Mar 31. 
5) The other buckets seem to be in play and it's a question in my mind of whether it's Memorial day (May 31, 2021) weekend or not.  I allocated my percentages subjectively. i don't see much point in going over 70% on the last bucket at this point.

"Air travel in the United States is unlikely to return to pre-pandemic levels before 2024, the head of a leading airline lobbying group said Thursday." https://www.washingtonpost.com/transportation/2020/09/03/it-could-be-least-2024-before-us-airline-industry-recovers-pandemic/

I used the data available from the TSA website to generate a polynomial formal (R=.9319, so not bad, but not great either).  y = 5.501E-6x^6-.0033x^5+.7837x^4-94.154x^3+6023.9x^2-187145x+2.228E+6 y = 2,000,000 Used Wolframalpha to solve [1] x = 196.521 round up to 197 197 days from today = March 20, 2021. Very imperfect way to forecast this question, but it's a start. [1] https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=2000000%3D5.501E-6x%5E6-.0033x%5E5%2B.7837x%5E4-94.154x%5E3%2B6023.9x%5E2-187145x%2B2.228E%2B6

3. But to get to March 8 (preCOVID) levels will take some rime to build up
4. Pent-up desire for leisure travel could provide a temp boost sometime in 2021 once a vaccine is out.

Basing this largely off vaccine timelines. I think you need widespread inoculation before travel with pick up. Business travel is likely permanently scarred and incomes will be down year-over year after stimulus works out of the system. Also, very few countries are accepting US travelers, so that limits it to domestic flying (about 75% of 2019 flights, most of which is leisure). The first two factors would imply “Not before 1 Oct 2021”, but the last sentence suggests it could pick up earlier. Sooner-than-expected could also be due to lockdown fever.  On the balance, I think the risks are skewed towards H2, 2021 since it is unlikely that a spike in leisure can offset all the declines in business if one even comes.

2 million isn’t a big hurdle given there were days in 2,7-2,8 million range previously but:
. Rolls Royce (paid per use if engines and maintenance) have said could take 3-4 years for full return to travel
. Airline manufacturers also suggesting 2-4 years
. Joe and Jill Sixpack aware flying in aluminum tube in close quarters even with masks - after being in airports with people mixing no matter how you manage traffic - carries some inherent risks
. “Everyone” was travelling previously. A bit of a downturn will exacerbate return to normal On other side of ledger 
. Airlines have greatly reduced airfare to entice people back (over 60% off international travel for me)
. Airline and airport livelihood depend on usage. They are working on better testing and increasing isolation of crowds etc Regardless, as much as many people I know have some degree of wanderlust or going stir crazy, most are staying within their own borders.
Jan - March is weak already.  Believe it will be close in the Q2 2021 but not quite.
